awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Big Data Approach to Fundamental Paleoclimate Questions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to apply a Big Data approach, harnessing emerging standards for paleoclimate data, to address two fundamental questions in climate dynamics: (Q1) the spatial extent of abrupt changes in hydroclimate; and (Q2) How can knowledge of past temperature variations help reduce the spread of twenty-first century climate projections. The potential Broader Impacts include building capacity in Big Data analysis in the global paleoclimate community. All analyses will be shared as open-source computational narratives to disseminate best practices in paleo data science among early-career researchers, and to provide a template for future analyses of this kind.

Specifically, the researchers will leverage recent paleoclimate data synthesis efforts, as well as advances in the analysis of chronologically uncertain timeseries, to explore fundamental questions in Holocene paleoclimatology. The proposed work will also link paleoclimate data to future climate projections from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6) ensemble.  The project will provide training to early career scientists through three yearly workshops in data management and analysis based on workflows and methodology developed as part of this research. Additionally, the project will support one graduate student working at the intersection between paleoclimatology, data science, and climate modeling. Other Broader Impacts include outreach through the Young Researchers program and Center for Knowledge-Powered Interdisciplinary Data Science to expose high-school students and graduate students in data science to interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this collaborative research project, we have helped to improve the data-analytical capacity in the early career paleoclimate workforce. This was primarily achieved through a series of hackathons organized by the USC group leveraging code and data standards developed by the PIs. The materials created as a part of this effort are openly available and should serve as a valuable resource going forward.

The research component of this project primarily focused on applying big data techniques to help answer two important questions in paleoclimatology:

  1. How synchronous are hydroclimate regime transitions since the last deglaciation?

The USC group has applied various approaches to identifying abrupt changes in cave records (speleothems), which are believed to be related to water availability (hydroclimate). This has entailed the development of a new method based on Laplacian Eigenmaps of Recurrence Matrices (LERM) to identify both gradual and abrupt changes in the dynamics of such records (James et al, Paleoceanography & Paleoclimatology, in press). Applied to speleothems, this method, along with at least 3 others, concurs to show that the “4.2ka event”, which has been proposed as the onset of the latest geologic era (the Meghalayan) does not stand out in the context of the past 10,000 years. This puts into question the very notion of a regional, much less global, 4.2ka “event”, and is consistent with a broader analysis of all high-resolution paleohydrological records from this period throughout the globe. The USC group has also analyzed oxygen isotopes records in speleothems for their potential relationships with (1) insolation and (2) growth rate. The results show an inconsistent relationship to local insolation at orbital scale, even in the tropics. In northern latitudes, sections of low growth rates in speleothems are inversely correlated with temperature proxies from Greenland ice cores. In other latitudinal bands, this relationship is either not present or obscured by a lack of available records. This portion of the project continues through collaborative research grant #2002556.

  1. How can knowledge of past temperature variations help reduce the spread of twenty-first century climate projections?

Different global climate models (GCMs) have long disagreed about the amount of future warming associated with a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations (known as equilibrium climate sensitivity; ECS). The UCLA group found that differences in ECS are related to the amount of variability that GCMs exhibit from year-to-year over the past millennium, whereby GCMs with more variability have greater future warming (Cropper et al. 2023, Geophysical Research Letters). Paleoclimate reconstructions of past temperatures were then used in conjunction with this relationship to assess GCM performance and infer the most likely range for ECS through an emergent constraint framework. The past millennium data suggests that ECS is on the lower end of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s likely range of 2.5-4.0K. The UCLA group has also assessed the potential for past millennium soil moisture data across the Southwestern United States to be used to reduce the spread in GCM projections of future drying. We find that variations in near-surface soil moisture over the past 1000 years are well correlated with model disagreements in projections of twenty-first century drying across the Southwestern United States. This research is still being wrapped up as it bridges into another NSF project (#2303610), we expect to submit a manuscript in early 2024.

The research under this award has thus far led to 2 publications in and submissions to peer-reviewed scientific journals. An additional 2 papers are in preparation. Two graduate students have been fully or partially supported under this award, while several early career scientists have been trained through our series of hackathons.
